title: Who was the last king of Athens? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most ancient Greeks probably believed it was Codrus (Κόδρος). According to the legend, which is preserved in Lycurgus’ Against Leocrates, Codrus was the king of Athens during the so-called Dorian invasion, the forceful migration of Heracles’ descendants to southern Greece. The Dorians planned an attack on Athens and asked the oracle of Delphi about it. Pythia told them they would succeed unless they killed the king of the city. Codrus learned of the oracle and decided to willingly sacrifice himself for his compatriots. Disguised as a peasant, he approached the Dorian camp and provoked some soldiers, who killed him without a second thought. When an Athenian embassy came to the camp, revealed the truth and asked for their king’s body, the Dorians complied and lifted the siege. Athens abolished the office of king out of respect for Codrus’ sacrifice. His son Medon (Μέδων) succeeded him as arkhōn ‘lord, magistrate.’ Lycurgus uses the story as an exemplum; according to him, Codrus was one of the “brave kings of old who would choose to die for the safety of those they ruled over rather than live in another land.” That being said, Aristotle seems to disagree with this idea. Drawing from a different tradition, he mentions Codrus’ sons Medon and Acastus (Ἄκαστος) as his successors to the kingship. It’s also worth mentioning that the title of basileus ‘king’ existed in Athens during the Archaic and Classical eras and beyond. Arkhōn basileus ‘magistrate king’ was an annually chosen magistrate, one of the nine magistrates of the city, and in fact the highest ranking among them. In this sense, he can be paralleled to a modern head of state. His powers were not extensive—they revolved around religious and judicial duties.
